Title: Assessing the effectiveness of sequence diagrams in the comprehension of functional requirements: results from a family of five experiments

Venue: IEEE Canadian Journal of Electrical and Computer Engineering

Cognitive weight of software (the degree of difficulty or relative time and effort required for comprehending a given piece of software modelled by a number of basic control structures)
Total cognitive weight of a software component (the sum of the cognitive weights of the basic control structures in the component)
Unit of cognitive weight of software (the cognitive weight of the simplest software component with only a single I/O and a linear basic control structure)
Cognitive functional size (a product of the sum of inputs and outputs and the total cognitive weight)
Cognitive Measures: Cognitive functional size (cognitive complexity of source code)

Title: Characteristics of the mental representations of novice and expert programmers: an empirical study
Cognitive Concepts: Several findings regarding the abstract characteristics of mental representations are discussed
Cognitive Measures:
Abstract characteristics of mental representations of programs
- Hierarchically structured mental representations
- Explicit mappings between layers of the representation
- The use of recurring basic patterns for knowledge representation
- Well-connected representation enhancing understanding of how parts of the program interact
- Representations well-grounded in the program text enhancing the localisation of structures and operations
Assessment:
Experimental task
- Reading a 135 line Pascal program.
- Answering questions that investigate the five abstract characteristics.
- The questions ask the participant to, e.g. match procedure names to the procedures they call, listing procedure names, writing descriptions of goals (of procedures and entire program), labelling code segments, listing names used for the same data objects in different program units, listing important variable names, filling in names of program units in a program outline, matching variable names to procedures where they occur, and indicating physical location of invariant program parts.
- Evaluation of questions/task results by two independent judges.

Theories of perception
Theories of perceptual organisation
Theories of perceptual segregation

(Visual) perception
- Cognitive functions as filters on raw visual stimuli (Marr, 1982)
- Attention shifting based on structure of environment (Gibson, 1979)
- Gestalt theory (Benjafield, 1992; Moore & Fitz, 1993)
- Theory of notation (Petre, Blackwell & Green, 1998)
Perceptual organisation (Boff, Kaufman & Thomas, 1896)
- Law of good figure (Prägnanz, Schiffman, 2001)
- Law of similarity
- Law of continuation
- Law of proximity
- Law of connectedness
- Law of familiarity
Perceptual segregation (Goldstein, 2002)
- Law of symmetry
- Law of orientation
- Law of contour (Kimchi, Berhmann & Olson, 2003)
Cognitive Measures: Several criteria for assessing the different aspects of visual perception, perceptual organisation, and perceptual segregation in UML diagrams
